Did you know that Barberton's in person learning plan is considered a "hybrid" by the Summit County Health Department? That means while some schools don't have enough classrooms for all students to come in safely (which is why they only attend in person a couple of day a week), Barberton's plan maintains small class sizes with physical distancing because we have 15 or fewer students in every classroom!

Having a hybrid plan right now is important because our students and staff can be 6 feet apart and still deliver high quality, in person education to 2700+ students, with 1200 choosing our remote option!

As COVID-19 continues to evolve in our area and throughout the state and country, we will continue to evaluate how things are going and always do what's safe for students and staff!

The Summit County Health Department will be in to review how we are doing periodically. I look forward to their visits and feedback.

We can do this, welcome back safely, see you tomorrow, and let's stay Barberton strong!

August 17, 2020 will mark 5 months since we closed our buildings and transformed into a new way of delivering education and support to our students and community due to the COVID-19 public health crisis!

This has been hard on families and students in so many different ways.

Today we want to bring your attention to a hidden danger - backsliding in education.

The Brookings Institution has studied this. We encourage you to read their report.

A normal summer slide means that when kids aren't in school the academic muscles they have built start to weaken. That happens over the 10-12 weeks of summer where they are not in school.

August 17 means it's been 20 weeks since they were in school.

We are going to being sharing some resources and other ways you can challenge your students to begin rebuilding their academic muscles this summer - to prepare them for Fall AND their future!

https://www.brookings.edu/blog/brown-center-chalkboard/2020/05/27/the-impact-of-covid-19-on-student-achievement-and-what-it-may-mean-for-educators/

In order to follow several safety guidelines in our plan - and continue to provide busing at 1 mile and further for Grades PreK - 8 - we have to suspend busing for BHS students for the 2020-2021 school year. The goal was for us to preserve busing for as many students as possible this school year!

It is our intention to continue busing for BHS students after the 2020-2021 school year is over.

From a safety standpoint, we can only have 1 child per seat on the bus.

Staggered start and end times at each building help us make our busing schedule as flexible as possible this year AND ensure that large groups of students aren't entering / exiting our buildings at the same time... provide more physical distancing at each school buildings.

The start and end times for each building will be defined in our plan.

All of these measures were put into place to make sure we can continue to bus all of our youngest students and to keep students and staff organized and as safe as possible.

#PurplePride

Mr. McComas's students at Barberton Middle School have been celebrating African and African American mathematicians this month.

Students had the opportunity to choose a prominent person, place, or artifact to focus their project on. Topics included the Lebombo Bone, the Moscow Papyrus, Harriet Tubman's escape routes, the Egyptian Pyramids, Katherine Johnson's time at NASA, Mancala, and Benjamin Banneker to name a few.

Students shared their newfound knowledge by creating slideshows, physical representations, posters, board games, homemade videos, and gameshows. Needless to say, it was a very successful project!

The undercount of school-aged children across the United States in the Census greatly affects the distribution of federal funding.

The 2020 Census data will determine congressional representation as well as how federal funding is distributed to states and communities. This funding will affect hospitals, social and education services, shelters, parks, churches, schools, businesses and infrastructure in Barberton and Summit County as a whole.

An estimated 5 percent of kids under the age of 5 weren’t counted in the 2010 Census. That’s about 1 million young children, the highest of any age group.

We need your help closing this gap in the 2020 Census! By April 1st, every home will receive an invitation to participate in the 2020 Census. Please do your part in helping to gather accurate data!

Check out what BHS chemistry students are up to!

Chemistry students have been exploring how materials give off light. It’s all about the electrons! After learning about challenging concepts like photons and quantum theory, students apply their knowledge to the world around them. In the last weeks, students have explored flames colors produced by metals, neon lights that aren’t really Neon, fluorescence and ‘glow-in-the-dark.’

The chemistry department has also just purchased a material testing machine with generous grant funding through PPG. This will enhance the outstanding material science program within the chemistry course where students study and make plastics, metals and ceramics.

This is one of the ways that BHS prepares students for future career and collegiate opportunities. Ohio was ranked by the Bureau of Labor Statics in May 2018 as the state with the 4th highest concentration of material science jobs and 3rd highest employment of material scientists.
